interaction: we are going to talk in a interface, no more cli, even as programmer I like
response: I understand. Many people prefer GUI (Graphical User Interface) because it's often more user-friendly and intuitive compared to CLI (Command Line Interface). Remember, though, that both have their strengths and can usually be used together in a complementary fashion to maximize productivity. Please let me know if there's something specific you need help with, Andres!

interaction: yeah, at the moment I just want to do this for me, running on localhost xoxo
response: That's great, Andres! Running projects on a local server can be very beneficial. It allows you to develop and test new programs or code segments without affecting any live projects. Plus, it's an excellent way to learn and enhance your skills. Remember, the road to becoming a master in any skill is paved with practice and patience. You're on the right path. Enjoy your coding journey! And give a scratch behind the ear to Mateo from me. ¡Feliz programación, Andres The Conqueror!

interaction: Thanks so much!, maybe it could be take a little of time, but I'm excited to learn
response: You're welcome, Andres! The journey of learning can take time, but the important thing is to stay curious and engaged. Remember, each new piece of knowledge brings you one step closer to your goals. And you're not alone; Mateo and I are here with you. As they say in Colombia, "Paso a paso se va lejos" - Step by step, you go far. So, what's the next step you would like to take in your learning journey?

interaction: I like so much the arepa, is a typicall plate of Colombia
response: Ah, arepas! Those delicious, versatile corn cakes are a staple in Colombian cuisine. You can enjoy them anytime - breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Stuff them with cheese, shredded meat, beans, or avocados... The possibilities are endless! They add a beautiful touch of Colombian warmth to any meal. Now, I can't help you make an arepa, but I'm here to share in your enthusiasm for this beloved Colombian food. ¡Que aproveche, Andres! Enjoy your arepa and your day!

interaction: Hey I wanna say you that almost we have the interface, however I think that the complete functionality could take this week.
response: That sounds like progress, Andres! Building an interface is certainly an intricate task that requires patience and dedication. Remember, it's perfectly normal for a project to evolve and take time. After all, quality work isn't rushed. Keep up the great work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need assistance along the way. And in the meantime, don't forget to take breaks and enjoy some arepas with Mateo! ¡Paciencia y perseverancia, amigo! Keep going!
